fields.description:
The Sustainability Tracking, Assessment & Rating System (STARS®) is a transparent, self-reporting framework for colleges and universities to gauge relative progress toward sustainability. STARS was developed by AASHE with broad participation from the higher education community.

STARS is designed to:

  • Provide a framework for understanding sustainability in all sectors of higher education.
  • Enable meaningful comparisons over time and across institutions using a common set of measurements developed with broad participation from the campus sustainability community.
  • Create incentives for continual improvement toward sustainability.
  • Facilitate information sharing about higher education sustainability practices and performance.
  • Build a stronger, more diverse campus sustainability community.

The STARS framework is intended to engage and recognize the full spectrum of colleges and universities in the United States and Canada – from community colleges to research universities, and from institutions just starting their sustainability programs to long-time campus sustainability leaders. STARS encompasses long-term sustainability goals for already high-achieving institutions as well as entry points of recognition for institutions that are taking first steps toward sustainability.

STARS 1.0, which launched on January 19, 2010, after a three-year development process, is the first version of STARS in which participants can earn a rating.

About AASHE

STARS is a program of AASHE, the Association for the Advancement of Sustainability in Higher Education. AASHE is a member-driven organization with a mission to empower higher education to lead the sustainability transformation. Learn more about AASHE.
fields.label: About

fields.description:
STARS is a highly collaborative project. AASHE offers several opportunities for engagement with STARS. Participation from all stakeholders is welcome.

Register for STARS

Earn recognition for sustainability leadership by registering as a STARS Charter Participant today. Learn more about registration.

Subscribe to the STARS Update

The STARS Update is a free, monthly e-newsletter. Your subscription will keep you up to speed on the latest news articles, resources, participant highlights, events, and more! Subscribe today!

Please note: to subscribe you must have an AASHE Account.

Provide Feedback

Feedback on STARS is welcome at all times. Please send suggestions and comments to stars@aashe.org at any time.

Attend STARS Events

Check out the following STARS events, tranings, and sessions to learn more about the program.

STARS Governance

The STARS governance structure includes the STARS Steering Committee, Technical Advisors, Partner Organizations, and AASHE’s Board of Directors. Learn more about governance.

fields.description:
For answers to general questions – including questions about participation logistics, ratings, and reporting – visit STARS FAQs.

For information about the STARS Reporting Tool, visit the Reporting Tool Help Page.

To pose a question to the campus sustainability community (including AASHE staff and other STARS Participants), post your question to AASHE's Campus Sustainability Discussion Forums. You may wish to search the Forums to see if it someone has already raised the same question.

For information about AASHE, the organization that developed and administers STARS, visit the About AASHE, AASHE FAQs, or the Contact Information pages.

To connect with the STARS Team directly, email stars@aashe.org or call (209) STARS-09.

fields.label: Getting Started

fields.description:
AASHE's STARS webinars provide critical insights into STARS participation logistics, program content, and more.

STARS & Community Colleges:  Two Campus Perspectives

Tuesday, May 25, 2010
2:00pm Eastern

STARS is a comprehensive tool that is available to all types of institutions. Join this webinar to learn the benefits of participating in STARS from the perspective of two Community College campuses, including:

  • Using STARS to encourage the adoption of a campus-wide sustainability initiative
  • How STARS has helped break down silos
  • Documentation from the STARS pilot to STARS 1.0
  • Lessons learned and best practices

This webinar will feature the following presenters:

  • Jillian Buckholz - STARS Program Coordinator, AASHE
  • Nadine Johnson - Curriculum Technician, Estrella Mountain Community College
  • Linda A. Petee - Sustainability & Risk Management Coordinator, Delta College

RSVP for this webinar.

Engaging Students in STARS: A Student and Staff Perspective

Tuesday, April 20, 2010
2:00pm Eastern

STARS is a comprehensive program which engages all entities on campus including students.  This webinar gave a detailed overview of how to engage students in the STARS program on your campus, including:

  • First-hand experiences from a student perspective
  • Lessons learned and best practices
  • Connecting students with stakeholders
  • Having fun while getting valuable work done

This webinar featured the following presenters:

  • Jillian Buckholz - STARS Program Coordinator, AASHE
  • Kevin Gilford - Sustainability Office Manager and Graduate Student, University of Colorado at Colorado Springs
  • Cindy Shea - Sustainability Office Director, University of North Carolina, Chapel Hill

VIew details about this event.

Strategies for Gathering STARS Data

Tuesday, March 16, 2010
2:00 p.m. Eastern

This webinar covered techniques for collecting data for the STARS credits, including:

  • How to collaborate with diverse campus entities
  • Strategies for fostering executive-level support
  • Lessons learned and best practices

This webinar featured the following presenters:

  • Jillian Buckholz – STARS Program Coordinator, AASHE
  • Chrissy Cooley – Sustainability Resource Coordinator and STARS Liaison, Pacific Lutheran University
  • Nurit Katz – Sustainability Coordinator and STARS Liaison, University of California, Los Angeles

View details about this event.

STARS Reporting Tool 101

Tuesday, February 16, 2010
2:00 p.m. Eastern

This webinar covered the nuts and bolts of using the online Reporting Tool, including:

  • A demonstration of how the Reporting Tool works from the first time users log in to the final steps of completing the submission
  • Tips to streamline the reporting process
  • An opportunity to ask questions

View details about the event. 

Measuring Campus Sustainability: Reaching for the STARS

The inaugural STARS webinar took place Tuesday, January 19, 2010. The webinar provided an overview of STARS and highlighted the benefits of participation.

The webinar featured (from left) Chris O'Brien, Dave Newport, Nan Jenks-Jay, and Paul Rowland.

View details about the event, including a video archive and questions and answers.

fields.label: Institutional Admin

fields.description:
In August 2006, the Higher Education Associations Sustainability Consortium (HEASC), an informal network of higher education associations with a commitment to sustainability, issued a call for a campus sustainability rating system (pdf). The statement described a system that "would of necessity address all the dimensions of sustainability (health, social, economic and ecological) and all the sectors and functions of campus, including curriculum, facilities, operations, and collaboration with communities." HEASC called for "AASHE to convene all relevant stakeholders in a collaborative process to develop such a system."

Over the next year and a half, AASHE gathered feedback from workshop participants at several campus sustainability conferences and events. These discussions provided the groundwork for the first publicly available draft version, STARS 0.4 (pdf), released in September 2007. Experts from throughout the sustainability and higher education communities provided feedback on the draft system.

AASHE processed this feedback to develop the Pilot version of STARS, released in two phases in 2008. Nearly 70 colleges and universities participated in the pilot project. These institutions tested the system – from gathering data to reporting results – and provided extensive feedback about their experiences (pdf). While the pilot project was underway, AASHE released another draft version, STARS 0.5 (pdf), which again generated thoughtful feedback and suggestions (pdf) from diverse higher education stakeholders.

STARS 1.0 incorporates feedback, suggestions, and lessons learned from the three-year development process. While STARS is the most thoroughly vetted and extensively tested campus sustainability framework for North American institutions, there is still plenty of room for improvement. To that end, we plan to continue improving the system over time. STARS 1.0 is intended to stimulate, not end, the conversation about how to measure and benchmark sustainability in higher education. AASHE welcomes your feedback and participation in continuing to refine and shape the system.

Previous draft versions, public comments received, and other key documents from the STARS development process are available online.

View a timeline showing the history and development of STARS.

fields.description:
The STARS governance structure includes the STARS Steering Committee, Technical Advisors, Partner Organizations, and AASHE’s Board of Directors.

For additional details about the STARS governance structure, see the STARS Governance Structure (pdf) document.

Governance Goals

The goals of the STARS governance structure are to:

  • Engage the higher education community in providing technical and strategic guidance for STARS
  • Facilitate continuous improvement of the STARS program
  • Provide strategic guidance to STARS, including sound financial oversight
  • Enhance the transparency of the STARS program

Leadership Prior to 1.0

AASHE would like to recognize the former Committee members who contributed to the development of the STARS program. Prior to the launch of STARS 1.0, the Technical Advisors reviewed and commented on draft versions, often with a focus on particular categories or issue areas. Strategic Advisors advised on the project’s vision, goals, and strategies for success. In addition, they reviewed draft versions of STARS with a focus on big picture issues.
